config.text: What should you do if you're driving a slow-moving vehicle on a narrow winding road?

choices.label: Keep well out to stop vehicles overtaking dangerously
Wave the vehicles behind to come past you if you think they can overtake quickly
Pull in when you can, to let the vehicles behind overtake
Give a left signal when it's safe for vehicles to overtake you

correct.text: If you’re driving a slow-moving vehicle along a narrow road, try not to hold up faster traffic. If you see vehicles following behind, pull over in a safe place and let the traffic pass before continuing. Don't wave other traffic past – this could be dangerous if you or they haven’t noticed a hazard ahead.

incorrect.text: If you’re driving a slow-moving vehicle along a narrow road, try not to hold up faster traffic. If you see vehicles following behind, pull over in a safe place and let the traffic pass before continuing. Don't wave other traffic past – this could be dangerous if you or they haven’t noticed a hazard ahead.

config.text: You're driving behind a large goods vehicle. What should you do if it signals left but steers to the right?

choices.label: Slow down and let the vehicle turn
Drive on, keeping to the left
Overtake on the right of it
Hold your speed and sound your horn

correct.text: Large, long vehicles need extra room when making turns at junctions. They may move out to the right in order to make a left turn. Keep well back and don't attempt to pass them on their left.

incorrect.text: Large, long vehicles need extra room when making turns at junctions. They may move out to the right in order to make a left turn. Keep well back and don't attempt to pass them on their left.

config.text: What must you do when the amber light is flashing at a pelican crossing?

choices.label: Stop and wait for the green light
Stop and wait for the red light
Give way to pedestrians waiting to cross
Give way to pedestrians already on the crossing

correct.text: Pelican crossings are signal-controlled crossings operated by pedestrians. Push-button controls change the signals. Pelican crossings have no red-and-amber stage before green; instead, they have a flashing amber light. This means you must give way to pedestrians who are on the crossing but if the crossing is clear you can continue.

incorrect.text: Pelican crossings are signal-controlled crossings operated by pedestrians. Push-button controls change the signals. Pelican crossings have no red-and-amber stage before green; instead, they have a flashing amber light. This means you must give way to pedestrians who are on the crossing but if the crossing is clear you can continue.

config.text: What type of emergency vehicle is fitted with a green flashing beacon?

choices.label: Fire engine
Road gritter
Ambulance
Doctor's car

correct.text: A green flashing beacon on a vehicle means the driver or passenger is a doctor on an emergency call. Give way to them if it's safe to do so. Be aware that the vehicle may be travelling quickly or may stop in a hurry.

incorrect.text: A green flashing beacon on a vehicle means the driver or passenger is a doctor on an emergency call. Give way to them if it's safe to do so. Be aware that the vehicle may be travelling quickly or may stop in a hurry.

meta.xref: DES s7, DES s10, HC r222

config.text: What will happen if you follow this vehicle too closely?

choices.label: Your brakes will overheat
Your fuel consumption will be increased
Your engine will overheat
Your view ahead will be reduced

correct.text: Staying back will increase your view of the road ahead. This will help you to see any hazards that might occur and give you more time to react.

incorrect.text: Staying back will increase your view of the road ahead. This will help you to see any hazards that might occur and give you more time to react.

config.text: What should you do when you're overtaking a horse and rider?

choices.label: Sound your horn as a warning
Go past as quickly as possible
Flash your headlights as a warning
Go past slowly and carefully

correct.text: Horses can be startled by the sound of a car engine or the rush of air caused by a vehicle passing too closely. Keep well back and only pass when it's safe. Leave them plenty of room; you may have to use the other side of the road to go past safely.

incorrect.text: Horses can be startled by the sound of a car engine or the rush of air caused by a vehicle passing too closely. Keep well back and only pass when it's safe. Leave them plenty of room; you may have to use the other side of the road to go past safely.

meta.xref: DES s1, DES s10, HC r214

config.text: What should you do when a person herding sheep asks you to stop?

choices.label: Ignore them as they have no authority
Stop and switch off your engine
Continue on but drive slowly
Try to get past quickly

correct.text: If someone in charge of animals asks you to stop, you should do so and switch off your engine. Animals are unpredictable and startle easily; they could turn and run into your path or into the path of another moving vehicle.

incorrect.text: If someone in charge of animals asks you to stop, you should do so and switch off your engine. Animals are unpredictable and startle easily; they could turn and run into your path or into the path of another moving vehicle.

meta.xref: DES s5, DES s10, HC r110-111

config.text: When should you flash your headlights at other road users?

choices.label: When showing that you're giving way
When showing that you're about to turn
When telling them that you have right of way
When letting them know that you're there

correct.text: You should only flash your headlights to warn others of your presence. Don't use them to greet others, show impatience or give priority to other road users, because they could misunderstand your signal.

incorrect.text: You should only flash your headlights to warn others of your presence. Don't use them to greet others, show impatience or give priority to other road users, because they could misunderstand your signal.

config.text: On a road where trams operate, which vehicles will be most at risk from the tram rails?

choices.label: Cars
Cycles
Buses
Lorries

correct.text: The narrow wheels of a bicycle can become stuck in the tram rails, causing the cyclist to stop suddenly, wobble or even lose balance altogether. The tramlines are also slippery, which could cause a cyclist to slide or fall off.

incorrect.text: The narrow wheels of a bicycle can become stuck in the tram rails, causing the cyclist to stop suddenly, wobble or even lose balance altogether. The tramlines are also slippery, which could cause a cyclist to slide or fall off.

meta.xref: DES s7, DES s10, DES s11, HC r126

config.text: The conditions are good and dry. When should you use the 'two-second rule'?

choices.label: Before restarting the engine after it has stalled
When checking your gap from the vehicle in front
Before using the 'Mirrors - Signal - Manoeuvre' routine
When traffic lights change to green

correct.text: In good conditions, the 'two-second rule' can be used to check the distance between your vehicle and the one in front. This technique works on roads carrying faster traffic. Choose a fixed object, such as a bridge, sign or tree. When the vehicle ahead passes this object, say to yourself 'Only a fool breaks the two-second rule.' If you reach the object before you finish saying this, you're too close.

incorrect.text: In good conditions, the 'two-second rule' can be used to check the distance between your vehicle and the one in front. This technique works on roads carrying faster traffic. Choose a fixed object, such as a bridge, sign or tree. When the vehicle ahead passes this object, say to yourself 'Only a fool breaks the two-second rule.' If you reach the object before you finish saying this, you're too close.

config.text: You're driving along this road. What should you do if the red car cuts in close in front of you?

choices.label: Accelerate to get closer to the red car
Give a long blast on the horn
Drop back to leave the correct separation distance
Flash your headlights several times

correct.text: There are times when other drivers make incorrect or ill-judged decisions. Be tolerant and try not to retaliate or react aggressively. Always consider the safety of other road users, your passengers and yourself.

incorrect.text: There are times when other drivers make incorrect or ill-judged decisions. Be tolerant and try not to retaliate or react aggressively. Always consider the safety of other road users, your passengers and yourself.

meta.xref: DES s7, DES s8, HC r179

config.text: You wish to turn right ahead. Why should you take up the correct position in good time?

choices.label: To allow other drivers to pull out in front of you
To give a better view into the road that you're joining
To help other road users know what you intend to do
To allow drivers to pass you on the right

correct.text: If you wish to turn right into a side road, take up your position in good time. Move to the centre of the road when it's safe to do so. This will allow vehicles to pass you on the left. Early planning will show other traffic what you intend to do.

incorrect.text: If you wish to turn right into a side road, take up your position in good time. Move to the centre of the road when it's safe to do so. This will allow vehicles to pass you on the left. Early planning will show other traffic what you intend to do.

config.text: Why should you never wave people across at pedestrian crossings?

choices.label: Another vehicle may be coming
They may not be looking
It's safer for you to carry on
They may not be ready to cross

correct.text: If people are waiting to use a pedestrian crossing, slow down and be prepared to stop. Don't wave them across the road, because another driver may not have seen them, may not have seen your signal, and may not be able to stop safely.

incorrect.text: If people are waiting to use a pedestrian crossing, slow down and be prepared to stop. Don't wave them across the road, because another driver may not have seen them, may not have seen your signal, and may not be able to stop safely.

config.text: Which vehicle will use a blue flashing beacon?

choices.label: Motorway maintenance
Bomb disposal
Snow plough
Breakdown recovery

correct.text: Emergency vehicles use blue flashing lights. If you see or hear one, move out of its way as soon as it's safe and legal to do so.

incorrect.text: Emergency vehicles use blue flashing lights. If you see or hear one, move out of its way as soon as it's safe and legal to do so.

config.text: You're driving on a clear night. Which lights should you use if the national speed limit applies and there's a steady stream of oncoming traffic?

choices.label: Full-beam headlights
Sidelights
Dipped headlights
Fog lights

correct.text: Use the full-beam headlights only when you can be sure that you won’t dazzle other road users.

incorrect.text: Use the full-beam headlights only when you can be sure that you won’t dazzle other road users.

meta.xref: DES s6, HC r141, KYTS p35

config.text: What does it mean if the signs at a bus lane show no times of operation?

choices.label: The lane isn't in operation
The lane is only in operation at peak times
The lane is in operation 24 hours a day
The lane is only in operation in daylight hours

correct.text: Bus-lane signs show the vehicles allowed to use the lane and its times of operation. Where no times are shown, the bus lane is in operation 24 hours a day.

incorrect.text: Bus-lane signs show the vehicles allowed to use the lane and its times of operation. Where no times are shown, the bus lane is in operation 24 hours a day.

meta.xref: DES s3, DES s5, DES s10, HC r112

config.text: When should you use your vehicle's horn?

choices.label: To alert others to your presence
To allow you right of way
To greet other road users
To signal your annoyance

correct.text: You mustn't use your vehicle's horn between 11.30 pm and 7 am in a built-up area or when you're stationary, unless a moving vehicle poses a danger. Its function is to alert other road users to your presence.

incorrect.text: You mustn't use your vehicle's horn between 11.30 pm and 7 am in a built-up area or when you're stationary, unless a moving vehicle poses a danger. Its function is to alert other road users to your presence.

meta.xref: DES s10, DES s11, HC r126

config.text: Why is it dangerous to travel too close to the vehicle ahead?

choices.label: Your engine will overheat
Your mirrors will need adjusting
Your view of the road ahead will be restricted
Your sat nav will be confused

correct.text: 'Tailgating' is the term used when a driver or rider follows the vehicle in front too closely. It's dangerous because it restricts your view of the road ahead and leaves no safety margin if the vehicle in front needs to slow down or stop suddenly. Tailgating is often the underlying cause of rear-end collisions or multiple pile-ups.

incorrect.text: 'Tailgating' is the term used when a driver or rider follows the vehicle in front too closely. It's dangerous because it restricts your view of the road ahead and leaves no safety margin if the vehicle in front needs to slow down or stop suddenly. Tailgating is often the underlying cause of rear-end collisions or multiple pile-ups.

config.text: Which instrument-panel warning light would show that headlights are on main beam?

correct.text: You should be aware of all the warning lights and visual aids on the vehicle you're driving. If you're driving a vehicle for the first time, you should familiarise yourself with all the controls, warning lights and visual aids before you set off.

incorrect.text: You should be aware of all the warning lights and visual aids on the vehicle you're driving. If you're driving a vehicle for the first time, you should familiarise yourself with all the controls, warning lights and visual aids before you set off.

meta.xref: DES s7, DES s10, DES s11, HC r126

config.text: You're in a line of traffic. What action should you take if the driver behind is following very closely?

choices.label: Ignore the driver behind and continue to travel within the speed limit
Slow down, gradually increasing the gap between you and the vehicle in front
Signal left and wave the driver behind to come past
Move over to a position just left of the centre line of the road

correct.text: If the driver behind is following too closely, there’s a danger they’ll collide with the back of your vehicle if you stop suddenly. You can reduce this risk by slowing down and increasing the safety margin in front of you. This reduces the chance that you’ll have to stop suddenly and allows you to spread your braking over a greater distance. This is an example of defensive driving.

incorrect.text: If the driver behind is following too closely, there’s a danger they’ll collide with the back of your vehicle if you stop suddenly. You can reduce this risk by slowing down and increasing the safety margin in front of you. This reduces the chance that you’ll have to stop suddenly and allows you to spread your braking over a greater distance. This is an example of defensive driving.

config.text: You're approaching a zebra crossing. What should you do if pedestrians are waiting to cross?

choices.label: Give way to older and infirm people only
Slow down and prepare to stop
Use your headlights to indicate they can cross
Wave at them to cross the road

correct.text: As you approach a zebra crossing, look for pedestrians waiting to cross. Where you can see them, slow down and prepare to stop. Be especially careful of children and older people, who may have difficulty judging when it's safe to cross.

incorrect.text: As you approach a zebra crossing, look for pedestrians waiting to cross. Where you can see them, slow down and prepare to stop. Be especially careful of children and older people, who may have difficulty judging when it's safe to cross.

config.text: You're driving at night on an unlit road. What should you do if you're following another vehicle?

choices.label: Flash your headlights
Use dipped headlights
Switch off your headlights
Use full-beam headlights

correct.text: If you follow another vehicle with your headlights on full beam, they could dazzle the driver. Leave a safe distance and make sure that the light from your dipped beam falls short of the vehicle in front.

incorrect.text: If you follow another vehicle with your headlights on full beam, they could dazzle the driver. Leave a safe distance and make sure that the light from your dipped beam falls short of the vehicle in front.

config.text: What style of driving causes increased risk to everyone?

choices.label: Considerate
Defensive
Competitive
Responsible

correct.text: Competitive driving increases the risks to everyone and is the opposite of responsible, considerate and defensive driving. Defensive driving is about questioning the actions of other road users and being prepared for the unexpected. Don't be taken by surprise.

incorrect.text: Competitive driving increases the risks to everyone and is the opposite of responsible, considerate and defensive driving. Defensive driving is about questioning the actions of other road users and being prepared for the unexpected. Don't be taken by surprise.

config.text: You're driving in traffic at the speed limit for the road. What should you do if the driver behind is trying to overtake?

choices.label: Move closer to the car ahead, so the driver behind has no room to overtake
Wave the driver behind to overtake when it's safe
Keep a steady course and allow the driver behind to overtake
Accelerate to get away from the driver behind

correct.text: Keep a steady course to give the driver behind an opportunity to overtake safely. If necessary, slow down. Reacting incorrectly to another driver's impatience can lead to danger.

incorrect.text: Keep a steady course to give the driver behind an opportunity to overtake safely. If necessary, slow down. Reacting incorrectly to another driver's impatience can lead to danger.

config.text: You're waiting in a traffic queue at night. How can you avoid dazzling drivers behind you?

choices.label: Use the parking brake and release the footbrake
Keep your foot on the footbrake
Balance the clutch with the accelerator
Use the parking brake and footbrake together

correct.text: In queuing traffic, your brake lights can dazzle drivers behind you. If you apply your parking brake, you can take your foot off the footbrake. This will turn off the brake lights so that they can't dazzle the driver behind you.

incorrect.text: In queuing traffic, your brake lights can dazzle drivers behind you. If you apply your parking brake, you can take your foot off the footbrake. This will turn off the brake lights so that they can't dazzle the driver behind you.

config.text: Which colour follows the green signal at a puffin crossing?

choices.label: Steady red
Flashing amber
Steady amber
Flashing green

correct.text: Puffin crossings have infra-red sensors that detect when pedestrians are crossing and hold the red traffic signal until the crossing is clear. The use of a sensor means there's no flashing amber phase as there is with a pelican crossing.

incorrect.text: Puffin crossings have infra-red sensors that detect when pedestrians are crossing and hold the red traffic signal until the crossing is clear. The use of a sensor means there's no flashing amber phase as there is with a pelican crossing.

config.text: What should you do if a vehicle pulls out in front of you at a junction?

choices.label: Swerve past it and sound your horn
Flash your headlights and drive up close behind
Slow down and be ready to stop
Accelerate past it immediately

correct.text: Try to anticipate what other drivers might do. Look and plan ahead so that you're ready to respond safely if a hazard develops. Be tolerant of road users who make mistakes.

incorrect.text: Try to anticipate what other drivers might do. Look and plan ahead so that you're ready to respond safely if a hazard develops. Be tolerant of road users who make mistakes.

meta.xref: DES s7, DES s10, HC r126

config.text: When should you leave a two-second gap between your vehicle and the one in front?

choices.label: When it's raining
When it's dry
When it's icy
When it's foggy

correct.text: In good, dry conditions, a driver needs to keep a distance of at least two seconds from the car in front. This should allow enough space for you to stop if the driver in front has to stop suddenly.

incorrect.text: In good, dry conditions, a driver needs to keep a distance of at least two seconds from the car in front. This should allow enough space for you to stop if the driver in front has to stop suddenly.

meta.xref: DES s1, DES s11, HC r168

config.text: You're travelling at the legal speed limit. What should you do if the vehicle behind approaches quickly, flashing its headlights?

choices.label: Accelerate to make a gap behind you
Touch the brakes sharply to show your brake lights
Maintain your speed to prevent the vehicle from overtaking
Allow the vehicle to overtake

correct.text: Don’t enforce the speed limit by blocking another vehicle’s progress. This will only cause frustration. Allow the other vehicle to pass when you can do so safely.

incorrect.text: Don’t enforce the speed limit by blocking another vehicle’s progress. This will only cause frustration. Allow the other vehicle to pass when you can do so safely.

meta.xref: DES s7, HC r25, KYTS p145

config.text: Which type of crossing allows cyclists to ride across with pedestrians?

choices.label: Toucan
Puffin
Pelican
Zebra

correct.text: A toucan crossing is designed to allow pedestrians and cyclists to cross at the same time. Look out for cyclists approaching the crossing at speed.

incorrect.text: A toucan crossing is designed to allow pedestrians and cyclists to cross at the same time. Look out for cyclists approaching the crossing at speed.

config.text: You're approaching an unmarked crossroads. How should you deal with the junction?

choices.label: Accelerate and keep to the middle
Slow down and keep to the right
Accelerate and look to the left
Slow down and look both ways

correct.text: Be cautious, especially when your view is restricted by hedges, bushes, walls, large vehicles, etc. In the summer months, these junctions can become more difficult to deal with, because growing foliage may further obscure your view.

incorrect.text: Be cautious, especially when your view is restricted by hedges, bushes, walls, large vehicles, etc. In the summer months, these junctions can become more difficult to deal with, because growing foliage may further obscure your view.

config.text: You're travelling along a single-track road. There's a passing place on your right. What should you do if you see a vehicle coming towards you?

choices.label: Continue along the single-track road
Stop in the passing place
Move over onto the verge
Wait opposite the passing place

correct.text: When you meet oncoming vehicles on a single-track road, you should allow them to pass. You should pull into a passing place on your left or wait opposite a passing place on your right. Do not move onto the verge as there may be hidden hazards.

incorrect.text: When you meet oncoming vehicles on a single-track road, you should allow them to pass. You should pull into a passing place on your left or wait opposite a passing place on your right. Do not move onto the verge as there may be hidden hazards.

meta.xref: DES s7, DES s8, HC r143

config.text: You're in a one-way street and want to turn right. Where should you position your vehicle when there are two lanes?

choices.label: In the right-hand lane
In the left-hand lane
In either lane, depending on the traffic
Just left of the centre line

correct.text: When you’re in a one-way street and want to turn right, you should take up a position in the right-hand lane. This will allow other road users, not wishing to turn, to pass on the left. Indicate your intention and take up the correct position in good time.

incorrect.text: When you’re in a one-way street and want to turn right, you should take up a position in the right-hand lane. This will allow other road users, not wishing to turn, to pass on the left. Indicate your intention and take up the correct position in good time.

meta.xref: DES s7, HC r300, KYTS p34

config.text: Who should obey diamond-shaped traffic signs?

choices.label: Tram drivers
Bus drivers
Lorry drivers
Taxi drivers

correct.text: These signs apply only to tram drivers, but you should know their meaning so that you're aware of the priorities and are able to anticipate the actions of the driver.

incorrect.text: These signs apply only to tram drivers, but you should know their meaning so that you're aware of the priorities and are able to anticipate the actions of the driver.

config.text: What should you do to avoid fuel spillage?

choices.label: Check that your tank is only three-quarters full
Check that you've used a locking filler cap
Check that your fuel gauge is working
Check that your filler cap is securely fastened

correct.text: When learning to drive, it's a good idea to practise filling your car with fuel. Ask your instructor if you can use a petrol station and fill the fuel tank yourself. You need to know where the filler cap is on the car you're driving, so you know which side of the pump to park at. Take care not to overfill the tank and make sure you secure the filler cap correctly, so that no fuel leaks onto the road while you're driving.

incorrect.text: When learning to drive, it's a good idea to practise filling your car with fuel. Ask your instructor if you can use a petrol station and fill the fuel tank yourself. You need to know where the filler cap is on the car you're driving, so you know which side of the pump to park at. Take care not to overfill the tank and make sure you secure the filler cap correctly, so that no fuel leaks onto the road while you're driving.

config.text: You're driving a car that has a diesel engine. What can a loose filler cap on your fuel tank cause?

choices.label: It can make the engine difficult to start
It can make the roads slippery for other road users
It can improve your vehicle's fuel consumption
It can increase the level of exhaust emissions

correct.text: Diesel fuel can spill out if your filler cap isn't secured properly. This is most likely to occur on bends, junctions and roundabouts, where it will make the road slippery, especially if it's wet. At the end of a spell of dry weather, road surfaces may be especially slippery where diesel has been spilled but it hasn't been washed away by rain.

incorrect.text: Diesel fuel can spill out if your filler cap isn't secured properly. This is most likely to occur on bends, junctions and roundabouts, where it will make the road slippery, especially if it's wet. At the end of a spell of dry weather, road surfaces may be especially slippery where diesel has been spilled but it hasn't been washed away by rain.

meta.xref: DES s7, DES s10, DES s11, HC r126

config.text: What's the minimum time gap you should leave when following a vehicle on a wet road?

choices.label: One second
Two seconds
Three seconds
Four seconds

correct.text: Water will reduce your tyres' grip on the road. The safe separation gap of at least two seconds in dry conditions should be doubled, to at least four seconds, in wet weather.

incorrect.text: Water will reduce your tyres' grip on the road. The safe separation gap of at least two seconds in dry conditions should be doubled, to at least four seconds, in wet weather.

config.text: What should you do if you're being followed by an ambulance showing flashing blue lights?

choices.label: Pull over as soon as it's safe to do so
Accelerate hard to get away from it
Maintain your speed and course
Brake harshly and stop well out into the road

correct.text: Pull over in a place where the ambulance can pass safely. Check that there are no bollards or obstructions in the road that will prevent it from passing.

incorrect.text: Pull over in a place where the ambulance can pass safely. Check that there are no bollards or obstructions in the road that will prevent it from passing.

config.text: You're being overtaken by a long, heavily laden lorry. What should you do if it's taking a long time for it to overtake?

choices.label: Speed up
Slow down
Hold your speed
Change direction

correct.text: A long lorry with a heavy load will need more time to pass you than a car, especially on an uphill stretch of road. Slow down and allow the lorry to pass.

incorrect.text: A long lorry with a heavy load will need more time to pass you than a car, especially on an uphill stretch of road. Slow down and allow the lorry to pass.

guide_to_driving_buses_and_coaches.title: The Official DVSA Guide to Driving Buses and Coaches

guide_to_learning_to_drive.title: The Official DVSA Guide to Learning to Drive

guide_to_riding.title: The Official DVSA Guide to Riding - the essential skills
